results.title: This is for you Richard and Cath
results.brief_description: Dedicated to her son and daughter, Lesley’s tribute to her late husband recalls the love they shared for each other. From the place where they first met, to the last place they spent time together. Created as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ workshop in association with Vic Health and the Heart Foundation.

results.title: How to kill your husband
results.brief_description: Shirley’s father, a skilled mechanic and excellent drummer, suffered from heart disease. Shirley retells her father’s history, from the struggles of growing up during the depression to his now proud children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Made as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ in association with Vic Health and the Heart Foundation.

results.title: Heart disease
results.brief_description: Neil created this story as a document of how surviving a heart attack completely changed his life. Created as part of ‘The Heart of the Story / Telling Stories, Building Communities’ Digital Storytelling Project ACMI in association with the National Heart Foundation of Australia (Victorian Division) and supported by Vic Health.

results.title: For my girls
results.brief_description: Gabby uses her Digital Story to tell her daughters about the inspiring life of their father, who died of a heart attack at the age of 31. Created as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with the National Heart Foundation of Australia (Victorian Division) and in partnership with VicHealth.

results.title: GTA 6 in real life
results.brief_description: From TikToks of in-game successes (and failures) to live Twitch streams, social media and videogames are perfectly matched. Modern consoles often have built-in features that let users easily record their play to share online, but this video isn’t that. It looks like leaked footage of Grand Theft Auto 6’s new graphics, but it’s a real-world video mimicking the series’ old-school movements, gestures and streetscapes. It’s like digital cosplay and reflects a larger trend of social users recreating game worlds in real life – like giving strangers quests as if in a fantasy game – which highlights the blurring of online and offline life. It’s been viewed over 40m times and endlessly shared.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

From TikToks of in-game successes (and failures) to live Twitch streams, social media and videogames are perfectly matched. Modern consoles often have in-built features that let users easily record their play to share online, but this video isn’t that. It looks like leaked footage of Grand Theft Auto 6’s new graphics, but it’s a real-world video mimicking the series’ old-school movements, gestures and streetscapes. It’s like digital cosplay and reflects a larger trend of social users recreating game worlds in real life – like giving strangers side quests as if in GTA (embedded below) – which highlights the blurring of online and offline life. It’s been viewed over 40m times, but there are many versions out there. This TikTok from user @bryteosky features dialogue, sound effects, cinematic cut scenes, graphic overlays and an impressively large cast to further anchor reality to the game.
description_for_label: From TikToks of in-game successes (and failures) to live Twitch streams, social media and videogames are perfectly matched. Modern consoles often have built-in features that let users easily record their play to share online, but this video isn’t that. It looks like leaked footage of Grand Theft Auto 6’s new graphics, but it’s a real-world video mimicking the series’ old-school movements, gestures and streetscapes. It’s like digital cosplay and reflects a larger trend of social users recreating game worlds in real life – like giving strangers quests as if in a fantasy game – which highlights the blurring of online and offline life. It’s been viewed over 40m times and endlessly shared.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Heidi Halloween
results.brief_description: Heidi Klum is known for her dedication to halloween costumes, having previously dressed as the ogre version of Fiona from Shrek, Jessica Rabbit, and even an alien science experiment gone wrong. In 2022 she outdid herself, dressing in full-body prosthetics to party as an earthworm, while husband Tom Kaulitz dressed as a fisherman. The committed costume set social media abuzz as the internet considered that Klum finally had a concrete answer to the age-old question: would you still love me if I was a worm?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Heidi Klum is known for her dedication to halloween costumes, having previously dressed as the ogre version of Fiona from Shrek, Jessica Rabbit and even an alien science experiment gone wrong. In 2022 she outdid herself, dressing in full-body prosthetics to party as an earthworm, while husband Tom Kaulitz dressed as a fisherman. The committed costume set social media abuzz as the internet considered that Klum finally had a concrete answer to the age-old question: would you still love me if I was a worm?
description_for_label: Heidi Klum is known for her dedication to halloween costumes, having previously dressed as the ogre version of Fiona from Shrek, Jessica Rabbit and even an alien science experiment gone wrong. In 2022 she outdid herself, dressing in full-body prosthetics to party as an earthworm, while husband Tom Kaulitz dressed as a fisherman. The committed costume set social media abuzz as the internet considered that Klum finally had a concrete answer to the age-old question: would you still love me if I was a worm? More so, Klum’s elaborate costumes also pay homage to the movie-making magic of prosthetics and make-up.

group.title: Sidekicks and supervillains in Thor: Love and Thunder

results.title: The Last Tram
results.brief_description:
This film captured by John ‘Jack’ Anderson, documents the last tram ride through the city of Ballarat in 1971.

The footage was filmed in 1971, with titles and music added for an event held at the Regent Theatre in Ballarat on 5th March 2020, “Large as Life: celebrating the life John ‘Jack’ Anderson”.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a group of film competing in a wheelbarrow race (one person holding another’s ankles while they walk with their hands); running; collecting water in a pail; playing with dogs; rowing on a river or lake; and picnicking and lounging on the grass with 1920s cars behind. The film then shows people on a golfcourse and three women and a dog in the gardens of a large home.
